newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Christopher calls for N. Korea "gesture" toward South.
newsitem.headline: Christopher calls for N. Korea "gesture" toward South.

text.p: U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher on Saturday renewed a U.S. call for North Korea to make a "gesture" toward the South to acknowledge its submarine incursion last September was a serious mistake.

The United States views the incursion as a "highly provocative incident (and) continues to believe the North Koreans should make a gesture that indicates they have a similar assessment of the seriousness of that action," he said on the eve of talks between the U.S. and South Korean presidents in Manila.

Christopher, who met his South Korean counterpart on Friday to prepare for the presidents' meeting on Sunday, said Washington and Seoul were in "total convergence" on dealing with the Stalinist North.

Both governments were committed to carrying out a 1994 landmark U.S.-North Korean nuclear accord, he said. Both were also "fully agreed on the importance of four-party talks" on a new peace agreement for the Korean peninsula as proposed by Washington and Seoul earlier this year, he said.

Tense relations between the two Koreas worsened after a North Korean submarine landed 26 suspected agents on a South Korean beach in September. Twenty-four of them were shot dead, one was captured alive and another is still at large.

South Korea had said it will suspend all assistance to the North, including financing the nuclear deal, until it "clearly apologises" for the submarine incident and guarantees such an incident will not be repeated. The North insists the incident was an accident.
